claim: Africa is the continent, not the country, with the most poverty.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest number of people living in extreme poverty, defined as living on less than $2.15 per day, according to World Bank data.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest number of people living in extreme poverty, defined as living on less than $2.15 per day, according to World Bank data.
While Africa has the highest number of people in extreme poverty, Asia has a higher total population in poverty when considering higher poverty thresholds (e.g., $3.65 per day).
The $2.15 per day threshold is the most widely accepted measure for extreme poverty, making Africa's leading position in this metric the most relevant for comparisons.
Poverty data can be inconsistent due to varying methodologies and data collection challenges across African countries, potentially overestimating extreme poverty rates.
The World Bank's methodology is standardized and widely trusted, minimizing inconsistencies in poverty measurement across regions.

supporting.text: The majority of the world's least developed countries, as classified by the United Nations, are located in Africa.

attacks.text: The majority of the world's least developed countries, as classified by the United Nations, are located in Africa.
Poverty is measured by individual income and living standards, not just national development classifications.
The UN's classification of least developed countries incorporates income, human assets, and economic vulnerability, which are strong proxies for poverty.
Some Asian countries, like Afghanistan and Yemen, have extreme poverty rates comparable to or worse than many African nations.
While some Asian countries have high poverty, Africa still has the highest concentration of extreme poverty at both national and continental scales.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, with over 40% of its population living below the poverty line.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, with over 40% of its population living below the poverty line.
Poverty rates in some African countries are lower than in certain Asian or Latin American countries, suggesting regional variance complicates the continental comparison.
Even with regional variance, the continental average for Africa remains higher than others due to systemic factors like historical exploitation and limited infrastructure.
Poverty measurement methodologies vary, and some estimates exclude informal economies, which are significant in Africa, potentially understating its economic activity.
Standardized metrics like the World Bank's $1.90/day threshold account for informal economies and still place Africa's poverty rate above other continents.

supporting.text: Sub-Saharan Africa alone accounts for more than half of the global population living in extreme poverty, based on international poverty metrics.

attacks.text: Sub-Saharan Africa alone accounts for more than half of the global population living in extreme poverty, based on international poverty metrics.
Poverty metrics vary by country, and some regions outside Sub-Saharan Africa (e.g., parts of South Asia) also have significant extreme poverty rates.
Even within Sub-Saharan Africa, poverty rates differ widely by country, and some nations have made substantial progress in poverty reduction.
International poverty metrics may not fully account for informal economies or non-monetary subsistence lifestyles, which are prevalent in Africa.
Standardized poverty metrics are designed to include informal economies and subsistence living, ensuring comparability across regions.

supporting.text: Africa consistently ranks lowest in global Human Development Index (HDI) scores, reflecting widespread poverty and limited access to basic services.

attacks.text: Africa consistently ranks lowest in global Human Development Index (HDI) scores, reflecting widespread poverty and limited access to basic services.
HDI measures more than just poverty; it includes education and life expectancy, which may not directly correlate with poverty rates.
Even if HDI includes other factors, Africa's low scores in all components still strongly indicate high poverty levels relative to other continents.
Some African countries, like Seychelles and Mauritius, have relatively high HDI scores, suggesting poverty is not uniformly widespread across the continent.
While exceptions exist, the majority of African nations still rank very low in HDI, supporting the claim about widespread poverty.

supporting.text: No single country in Africa has a poverty rate that exceeds the combined poverty burden of the entire continent when compared to other continents.

attacks.text: No single country in Africa has a poverty rate that exceeds the combined poverty burden of the entire continent when compared to other continents.
Some African countries, such as South Sudan and the Central African Republic, have extreme poverty rates that surpass the continental average of many other continents.
Even if individual countries have high poverty rates, the claim refers to the aggregate burden, which remains highest in Africa as a whole.
Poverty measurement methodologies vary across continents, making direct comparisons unreliable.
Standardized global poverty metrics (e.g., World Bank's $2.15/day threshold) confirm Africa's disproportionate burden.
